Cardiff Carnival 25th Anniversary Project.
Interviewer Steve Fletcher.
Interviewee Caroline Sevens.
Venue Swicker Office.
And the date today is Tuesday the 18th of November.
Caroline, would you be kind enough to spell your name in full for posterity?
Of course. C-A-R-O-L-I-N-E-S-E-M-M-E-N-S.
Thank you very much indeed.
So how did you first come into contact with Swicker?
I had graduated university in 2001 with an English degree, which allows you to do nothing.
So I knew I wanted to specialise in something.
So I came back to Cardiff and studied at the Royal Welsh College of Music and Drama
and did a post-grad in Arts Management.
Towards the end of my year there, we had to do a month work placement
and I worked for David Baxter in the Education Department of St David's Hall.
And whilst we were there, he was talking about what I wanted to do after I graduated.
And look for a job was obviously my main priority.
And he at the time was trustee for Swicker and said that there was a place coming up for an administrator,
as the administrator who'd been here for many, many years was leaving,
and put me forward for an interview, which I came to, got the job and the rest is history.
2002. So talking of history, how many Cardiff Carnivals did you help create and support
and run around like a crazy girl?
Looking at the list, I think it's four between 2002 and 2005,
starting with Citizenship and ending with Doc's Wales window on the world,
trading places in spirit of Mother Earth.
And do you still have the emotional scars?
Absolutely. Physical, emotional. No, not at all.
Yeah.
What are your memories of Cardiff Carnival?
Let's start with Cardiff Carnival in particular.
Well, I guess it's an unusual one for me being on an administrative side
rather than being a participator or an artist or a spectator.
I had seen the carnival.
I'd never deliberately come to see the carnivals, but I was very much aware of them.
I'd been in the place where they were happening, so I knew that they happened.
I hadn't obviously had any idea on the kind of background to them,
all the workshops that took place, all the hard work behind the scenes.
I only just witnessed the carnival day itself and the parade passing and thinking,
oh, that's spectacular and didn't think too much of it.
So, you know, coming from it from the other angle and seeing all the work
that was involved was a big, big eye-opener.
It was also my first, I say my first job.
I'd had jobs before, but, you know, a full-time permanent position in terms of the arts.
It was so it was, yeah, it was a massive eye-opener to see all the work
that went involved, all the people that kind of came and got involved,
the communities that built over those few months of the mass camps
and then the actual days itself.
And yeah, the actual parade is almost this kind of strange sense of anticlimax
of the fact that you've worked with these people, you know, day in, day out.
You know, for all the time leading up to it and in all the mass camps,
which were, you know, like a proper family and a community got built in those in those weeks.
And then whilst the parade was amazing, there was also that sense of and what happens now.
And, you know, for the people working on it, it wasn't too bad because back then,
we would shut down for a week, get everything back in a van and then ship to Swansea
and, you know, and do something in Swansea a few weeks later.
But yeah, it was a strange sense of amazing anticlimax.
I guess it's the same thing as putting on a theatre show.
You know, you work really hard, you do a show for a week and then that's it.
And you wave goodbye and hope to see each other next time.
So, yeah, it's an amazing experience.
Certainly that that that whole phenomena of post-Carnival blues is very real
because people get to a very positive space and they find themselves in this
sort of mini village of collective creativity.
And then they get to hopefully, well, generally be applauded and cheered,
sometimes in sunshine, sometimes in rain,
after which, yes, life seems a little less colorful and flamboyant, doesn't it?
I mean, that's a real phenomenon for people.
Yeah. And the Cardiff one for me, coming from Cardiff or just outside Cardiff
and, you know, living here my life and living a few years away from university.
It was it opened up a whole new part of Cardiff for me.
When I was growing up in a fairly middle class,
you know, upbringing, butan, you just wouldn't go to, you know, butan was rough.
It was scary. It was dangerous.
Ironically, my dad grew up in East Tindall Street.
You know, he was a docks boy and even he was kind of raising eyebrows about,
you know, it's changed since I was a boy back in the 1940s, 50s.
It's very different. There's a lot of black people there.
There's a lot of immigrants.
You know, is it safe to be there?
And yet I and I I hope it's still the same to this day.
What I found from Butan was the residents of Butan and what people
will class as the scary, the dangerous, the rough, the the unknown
quantity of Butan with the strongest community I've ever, ever experienced
and and have done since.
I mean, I'm not saying their lives were easy.
I'm sure they all had their, you know, their problems to deal with.
But the sense of community that was there and Fatima, who used to run
the the youth pavilion or manage the youth pavilion,
was just this amazing matriarch figure and had every single one of those young people.
You know, they they did whatever she said.
And mind you, I don't think I'd ever cross Fatima either.
But, you know, it was this amazing sense.
She knew them. She knew their family.
She knew their problems. She knew their positive sides.
And she would do everything to get them involved.
And that real sense of, you know, this wasn't a scary community at all.
It was just a very, very close knit community.
And to be allowed for those few years to be almost a part of that community
was actually I think it's a bit of a privilege.
You know, it's not very often you get to break into such a strong, strong community
and get to be a part of them for those for those few months.
And, you know, I went to Pumps in Butan that I would never, ever dream of going into.
Or since without their, you know, without their support,
I was going to say protection, but I'll use the word support still.
Yeah. And, you know, and just to think that that there was,
you know, these communities are out there and there's actually
not nothing that's scary about them.
But you got this perceived sense of threat or unknown.
And, yeah, it really broke down some barriers for me about, you know, working
outside my comfort zone.
Yes, I think Fatima's ultimate sanction was I'm going to go and tell your parents
because she could, you know, and they would listen to her and share that.
Her concerns.
